intro: Sida acuta subsp. carpinifolia, commonly known as the needleleaf sida, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a herbaceous annual that typically grows in disturbed soils and open habitats. The plant features slender, needle-like leaves that are opposite or whorled, giving it a distinctive appearance. Its small, white or pale pink flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and it produces small, capsule-like fruits. It is often found in wetland areas and is adapted to thrive in moist environments.
